title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Google Cloud) outlines how AI-aware networking—via GKE Inference Gateway, Cloud Load Balancing and GKE—optimizes inference by using specialized metrics (KV cache utilization, queue depth), prefix/body-based routing, and service extensions. These capabilities route requests to least-loaded replicas, reuse prefill/cache work to reduce cold starts and GPU waste, and insert guardrails at the network edge to block invalid prompts before they consume model compute.
bullets: AI workloads need inference-specific metrics (KV cache, queue depth) because CPU metrics don’t reflect GPU saturation.
GKE Inference Gateway + AI-aware load balancing uses prefix caching and shadow copies to reuse prefill computations and lower GPU load.
Body-based routing and LoRA-awareness let the network pick appropriate model replicas and APIs without complex topologies.
Service Extensions enable API management and AI guardrails in the traffic path to sanitize prompts/responses before hitting models.
Result: fewer cold starts, higher GPU saturation, lower latency, reduced TCO and compute waste.
takeaways: Higher GPU saturation changes power planning: expect more sustained rack-level power draw rather than just short CPU spikes—size PDUs, UPS and cooling for steady GPU loads.
Caching and prefill reuse reduce per-request compute and energy; deploy inference-aware routing to lower energy per inference and defer hardware expansion.
Network-edge guardrails can block invalid or unsafe requests before GPU use—implement edge filtering to save costly compute and associated energy.
Telemetry must include inference metrics (KV cache, queue depth) for accurate capacity planning and to avoid routing traffic to congested GPUs.
Low-latency, high-bandwidth intra-datacenter networking becomes more critical—ensure fabric and switch uplinks support the reduced-latency routing these strategies require.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this is a short showcase trailer for the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet highlighting NVIDIA's DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and RTX visuals. The clip promotes playing with #RTXOn and credits @DigitalDreamsyt.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet.
Showcases NVIDIA DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation.
Promotes RTX-on visuals (#RTXOn) and ray-traced rendering.
Video credited to @DigitalDreamsyt and published on NVIDIA GeForce (2026-01-14).
No transcript available in the provided content.
takeaways: Adoption of DLSS 4 and RTX implies growing demand for latest-generation GPUs—plan for higher GPU compute capacity and compatible server hardware.

Real-time, hardware-accelerated rendering and potential game-streaming workloads increase peak power, cooling, and networking requirements—ensure data center power provisioning and low-latency connectivity can meet spikes.
Higher GPU density and turnover can drive greater energy consumption variability—evaluate UPS, on-site energy storage, and renewables integration to support reliability and demand-response.
Expanded deployment of advanced GPUs may affect procurement and supply chains for critical minerals—consider supplier diversification, lifecycle planning, and recycling strategies.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this GE Vernova video stresses that a steam turbine rotor is the backbone of a steam plant’s reliability and highlights the importance of anticipating an aging rotor’s remaining life and planning next steps. It directs viewers to GE Vernova’s rotor EOL (end-of-life) resource and positions the company as a partner in managing rotor lifecycle and plant reliability.
bullets: Emphasizes assessing remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors.
Frames the rotor as central to steam plant reliability.
Encourages planning actions for rotor end-of-life (EOL).
Provides a link to GE Vernova’s rotor EOL resource for more information.
Connects viewers to GE Vernova’s channel and social platforms.
takeaways: Anticipate rotor remaining life to inform maintenance, refurbishment, or replacement timing and avoid unexpected reliability impacts.
Include rotor EOL planning in asset-management and outage scheduling to support continuous power delivery for grids and critical facilities.
Leverage vendor resources (e.g., GE Vernova’s rotor EOL offerings) for diagnostics, lifecycle assessment, and decision support.
Treat rotor lifecycle planning as part of broader plant reliability and modernization efforts, including decarbonization initiatives mentioned by GE Vernova.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG podcast discusses how the luxury goods market is transforming—shifting toward experiences, personalization, and ‘affordable luxury’ while ESG and responsible materials gain importance. The hosts highlight global trends (including ‘luxury fatigue’ and concentration of spending among the wealthiest), Poland’s growing but fragmented market, and future drivers like AI, craftsmanship and luxury tourism.
bullets: Global trends: ‘luxury fatigue’, concentrated spending (top 2% ≈ 40% of market).
Demand drivers: personalization, exclusive experiences, and aspirational consumers (including Gen Z prioritizing experiences).
ESG/Responsible luxury: rising focus on eco-materials, certifications and brand responsibility.
Poland-specific: market is still growing domestically but remains dispersed across players and segments.
Future themes: luxury in hospitality and culture, AI-enabled personalization, and continued emphasis on craft and human touch.
takeaways: Rising luxury tourism, premium hotels and branded experience spaces can drive localized increases in electricity and cooling demand—plan for reliable supply and on-site resilience.
ESG pressure on luxury brands suggests growing interest in on-site renewables, energy storage and green certifications—opportunities for partnerships and commercial PPAs.
Adoption of AI and advanced personalization in retail/hospitality will increase compute needs, accelerating demand for data-center capacity, low-latency edge computing and robust cooling solutions.

Fragmented but growing Polish luxury market implies multiple distributed projects (boutiques, galleries, hotels) that may need modular energy and backup solutions rather than single large deployments.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection has prioritized reliability since 1927. The video explains how PJM works to make sure electricity is there when you need it.
bullets: PJM has made reliability its primary mission since 1927.
The video focuses on how PJM works to ensure electricity is available when needed.
Content is framed around PJM’s role in keeping the power on for customers.
takeaways: If your operations are within PJM territory, factor PJM’s reliability processes into outage planning and contingency strategies.
Data center operators should coordinate with PJM for capacity and restoration planning to align backup strategies with regional reliability priorities.
Renewables and storage developers need to consider PJM interconnection and operational requirements to ensure their resources support grid reliability.
Planners and asset managers should monitor PJM communications and programs because reliability is central to regional grid decision-making.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames grid modernization as a balance of reliability, flexibility and efficiency while scaling capacity for the energy transition. The company highlights innovative power grid technologies with digitalization at the core to improve stability, reduce downtime and optimize performance across the system.
bullets: Focus on balancing reliability, flexibility and efficiency as capacity expands for the energy transition
Digital technologies are positioned as the core enabler for grid modernization
Aimed at improving grid stability and reducing downtime
Optimizes performance across system levels through innovative power grid solutions
takeaways: Prioritize digital-enabled controls and monitoring to boost stability and cut unplanned outages
Plan capacity growth with an eye to maintaining efficiency and operational flexibility
Evaluate grid technologies that provide system-wide performance optimization for substations, transmission and distribution
For data centers and renewables/storage projects, insist on solutions that minimize downtime and integrate with broader grid digital platforms

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames industrial resilience around energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy positions itself as a partner to help customers build smarter systems that improve productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Focus on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration as pillars of resilient industry.
Hitachi Energy collaborates with customers and partners to deliver system-level improvements.
Goals highlighted: higher productivity, improved reliability, and greater sustainability.
Emphasis on smarter systems rather than single-point products or services.
Call to learn more via the provided link.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency upgrades and process optimization in substations and data centers to boost resilience and lower operating cost.
Leverage digital integration (monitoring, analytics, control) to improve reliability and enable predictive maintenance across grid and facility assets.
Partner with experienced system integrators to deliver coordinated, cross-domain improvements rather than piecemeal fixes.
Frame sustainability metrics (efficiency, emissions, uptime) alongside productivity when evaluating upgrades or new projects.
